result.execSummary:
The defendant Jason A Jackson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Outstanding financial obligations are not a condition of probation & are to be paid directly to the Shawano Co Clerk of Court office within 30 days.  Debts older than 60 days will be processed for tax intercept & civil judgments.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Payment plans available for qualifying amounts.

All financials same as noted above.  
MUST SUBMIT DNA SAMPLE

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

Defendant Jason A Jackson in court with attorney Steven Edward Weerts.  Catharine Denise White appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Plea Questionnaire filed w/NC plea to Count 1, Count 2 DRI.  ADA Niemi makes recommendation. Court reviews rights, charges & penalties w/DE, Court accepts waiver, plea, finds factual basis and finds DE guilty of Count 1, DRI Count 2.  Sentencing arguments.  VIS statement filed, rights have been complied with.  Court follows recommendation.  Appeal rights given to DE.  DE reminded that prints are still needed.
